Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project re-conceptualizes STEM Innovation, Teaching, and Learning through the establishment of significant academic and community partnerships. Drawing from principles and best practices for engaged learning and creation of innovative learning environments, partners seek to develop a system of innovation and STEM learning across institutions that is woven into the cultural fabric of the region. Specifically, a team of student interns, their faculty, and community mentors will investigate and implement improvements to an impaired waterway and the surrounding economically challenged neighborhood in South Bend, Indiana. Collaborators for the Bowman Creek Educational Ecosystem include many partners: administrators and faculty from the University of Notre Dame, Indiana University at South Bend, Ivy Tech Community College, and Riley High School of South Bend; and community partners from the City of South Bend's Office of Innovation, neighborhood associations, and a community development corporation.

The proposed project is Phase I of a two-phase effort and has two key technical goals: 1) to advance the theory and knowledge of educational environments that contribute to building and strengthening the STEM pipeline from high school to graduate school; 2) to develop a collaborative and sustainable community/institutional infrastructure to support trans-disciplinary, authentic STEM learning for community impact. The approach taken is housed within an innovative framework designed to dig deeper for answers about STEM learning, engagement, knowledge, skill as well as the impact of economic deficits with which many post-industrial cities struggle. The research questions posed aim to generate knowledge about how perceptions of identity and possibility together with life experiences shape choices with regard to STEM at different levels of education and what factors facilitate or inhibit positive STEM collaboration. A variety of methods for seeking answers to the questions are adopted including exploratory sequential mixed methods for exploring STEM pathways and cultural domain analysis for generating cognitive maps of how students culturally understand STEM pathways at the beginning and end of the project. Participants in the project-based learning experience are ethnically and socio-economically diverse, furthermore, the research questions posed examine important issues such as the types of collaboration that take place in diverse student groups and their effect on students' recruitment, retention and perceived identity in STEM.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With support from an IUSE Exploration and Design grant, researchers developed, piloted, and examined a theory of change (ToC) for building a collaborative, interdependent network of educational institutions (RI/R2 universities, colleges, community colleges, and k-12) and community organizations (municipal, nonprofits, industry, foundations) that form a sustainable infrastructure for transdisciplinary authentic STEM learning opportunities. This Community-Engaged Educational Ecosystem Model (C-EEEM, pronounced ‘seam’) in South Bend, Indiana was conceptualized to transform not just a single institution, but the intersection between community and education for high school through graduate school STEM learning, with the emphasis on undergraduate education. By involving faculty, teachers, and administrators across the education sector and leaders in the public and nonprofit sectors, we expected and found steady movement toward this interdependent educational ecosystem the accompanying student outcomes.

With the investment from NSF IUSE, we were able to grow the C-EEEM effort from 14 interns, 3 community-engaged projects, 5 professional mentors, and 3 community partners in 2015 to 54 interns, 14 community-engaged projects, 48 professional mentors, and 24 community partners in 2019. The key outcome to report from the grant is the establishment of the Center for Civic Innovation (CCI) at the University of Notre Dame (UND). As a result of the proven track record of community and educational outcomes, UND is investing in the infrastructure needed to continue deploying the C-EEEM developed by the grant team.

The C-EEEM work has been disseminated widely through academic publications and presentations in Anthropology and Engineering Education:

  • Haanstad, E. (2017). “Security Ambiguities of a Collaborative Ecosystem Project in a Revitalizing City.” Human Organization journal of the Society for Applied Anthropology.
  • Huggins, K., Barnes, A., Blum, S.D., Brockman, J.B., Gilot, G.A., (2017). Engagement in Practice: Not Just Technical Education; An Anthropological Perspective on a Community-Based Engineering Internship Program. American Society of Engineering Education.
  • Krug, M., Brockman, J.B., Czarnecki, A., Nell, R., Gilot, G.A., Goodrich, V. (2017). Engagement in Practice: Bowman Creek Educational Ecosystem. American Society of Engineering Education.
  • Boukdad, S., Cuevas, A.B., Kennedy, M. (2018). Bowman Creek Academy: An Immersive STEM Experience.  American Society of Engineering Education.
  • Mayers, S.D., Londergan, E.M., Czarnecki, A., Brockman, J.B., Gilot, G.A., Goodrich, V.E., Hergenrother, M., Bruggeman, A., (2017). Engagement in Practice: Vacant Lot Optimization Matrix.  American Society of Engineering Education. 
  • Wood, D., Gura, A.Z., Brockman, J.B., Alptekin, S. (2018). Student Outcomes in Academic Community Engaged STEM projects with Multi-Dimensional Diversity. American Society for Engineering Education. 
  • Wood, D., Gura, A.Z., Brockman, J.B., Rayna Carolan-Silva, A., Boukdad, S., Alarcon, J., (2019). Informing Replication of the Bowman Creek Educational Ecosystem Pilot.  American Society for Engineering Education. 
  • Wood, D., Gura, A.Z., Brockman, J.B., Gilot, G.A., (2020). Critical Findings from the Bowman Creek Educational Ecosystem Pilot.  American Society for Engineering Education.
  • Wood, D., Gura, A.Z., Brockman, J.B., Donoghue, B., (2020). The Community-Engaged Educational Ecosystem Model (C-EEEM).  Community Development. (under review)
